title: Heat Lamp and Heat Plate Differences | Cackle Hatchery

tasks.task: Preparing and maintaining a brooder for mail-order baby chicks.
subtasks: Acquire a brooder reflector lamp, such as one with a 125-watt bulb.
Ensure the lamp has a guard to prevent accidental fires.
Use a red bulb to minimize stress on the chicks.
Determine appropriate heat lamp placement based on chick response (huddling indicates cold).
Adjust heat lamp wattage according to the number of chicks (125 watts for every 25 chicks).
Maintain brooder temperature at 100-105 degrees Fahrenheit at floor level upon arrival.
Gradually decrease heat source intensity as chicks grow older (after 7-10 days) using heat plates without heat lights.
Transition from heat lamps to heat plates after chicks are acclimated to avoid continuous light exposure.

tasks.task: Preparing and maintaining a brooder for mail-order baby chicks.
subtasks: Acquire a brooder reflector lamp suitable for warming the chicks and the air.
Ensure the lamp includes a safety guard.
Use a red bulb to reduce stress on the chicks.
Place the lamp according to chick behavior (adjust height or position as needed).
Determine the appropriate wattage based on the number of chicks (e.g., 125W for every 25 chicks).
Maintain the brooder temperature at 100-105°F at floor level immediately after arrival.
After 7-10 days, transition to a heat plate that does not produce light and heats the air.
Monitor chick behavior to adjust heat sources as they grow and acclimate.
